title: CTRL0000916059 - Transcribed Interview of Michael Shirkey, (June 8, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 1:02 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So this is the transcribed interview of Michael Shirkey conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
Mr. Shirkey, could you please state your full name and spell your last name for the
And, counsel, can you please identify yourself and spell your last
It's just the letter J, S-h-i-r-k-e-y.
Matthew Schneider, Honigman Law Firm, S-c-h-n-e-i-d-e-r, and
the law firm is H-o-n-i-g-m-a-n LLP.
My name i s _ , senior investigative counsel for the select
In the room today with me from the select committee is
may have members joining us from time to time.
arrival when they come into the interview.
One of my colleagues is on the Webex now,
I will do my best to announce their
This interview is being recorded, as you heard, but the official transcript of
this -- or the official record of it will be the transcript that's being prepared by the official
Because the reporter is taking down everything that's said during the interview, I
ask you to please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response,
and we'll try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head,
so it's important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
We ask you to provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
course, please simply just say so.
If you don't know the answer, of
I want to remind you, Senator Shirkey -- and this is not specific to you, this is an
admonition that we give to all witnesses -- I want to remind you that it's unlawful to
deliberately provide false information to Congress, and doing so could be a violation of
Title 18, United States Code, Section 1001, and other statutes.
Are there any questions about anything I've gone over so far?
If at any point during the interview today you need to take a break,
please just let me know, and we'll accommodate you and take as long a break as you
need either to talk to your attorney or for any other purpose.
With that, if you have a statement that you'd like to read before we get started,
now would be a good time.
The events that occurred on January 6th are vivid memories for me and my wife.
I think I may have mentioned the last time we talked that I can recall both of us sitting
there holding hands and in tears watching those events unfold.
I am happy to accommodate this interview, in addition to the one that previously
occurred, and I think it's important to get to the bottom of what actually occurred on that
I recognize that you're going to ask me a lot of questions that happened more
than 2 years -- or 2 years ago or so, and I will do my very best to do that based on the
And I also acknowledge that this is being recorded and on the
And thank you for being here today.
And thank you for those remarks.
I'm going to start with just a little bit of background.
Are you currently a member of the Michigan State Senate?
How long have you been in the State legislature in Michigan?
I've been in the legislature since 2011.
And all that time in the senate or were you in the house for some period of
I was in the house for two terms, plus a few weeks, and this is my second
The house was 2-year terms, two 2-year terms.
4-year terms, one 4-year term I've completed and the second 4-year term I'm in my
third -- or fourth year of that 4-year term.
Do you currently hold a leadership position in the senate?
How long have you been the senate majority leader?
And the term, you said you're 3 years into it, so that would have been
Let's go off the record for one second.
So let's go back on the record.
interactions that you had in the aftermath of the 2020 election.
I take it you were on the ballot in the 2020 -- oh, maybe I shouldn't.
Senator Shirkey, I'm going to focus our questions today on specific
on the ballot in the 2020 general election?
I was not on the ballot.
So your term is -- you were on the -- 2018 was the last time you were on a
Were you involved in campaigning on behalf of other Republican candidates
Did Republicans have the majority in the Michigan Senate going into the
And did it maintain that majority after the 2020 election?
Were the Republicans the majority in the
And have they retained that majority?
Did you actively campaign for President Trump in 2020?
I'm not sure the definition of actively campaign, but I attended some
meetings and rallies, not very many.
After the election did you have any direct personal interactions with
When was the first direct interaction you had with President Trump after the
So the best of my recollection, the first time I was interacting with the President
But there was no mystery about me supporting
Now I've got to refer to my notes so I don't get dates mixed up.
Was that a telephone call at approximately 6:07 p.m.?
Tell me what, if you know -- well, did you call the President or did he call
What was the purpose of that phone call?
He invited me to join the speaker of the house and visit the Oval Office a
Prior to receiving the call from the President, had you been alerted to the
fact that he might be calling to invite you to the White House?
How did you learn of that?
The speaker of the house told me that I might be getting a call from the
President of the United States and advised me that my display on my phone would say,
Was the speaker of the house at the time Lee Chatfield?
And Mr. Chatfield, did he tell you that he had already spoken to the
That was my notification for the fact that that might be him.
President about coming to the White House?
What do you remember specifically Mr. Chatfield telling you about the call
that he had with President Trump?
All I remember is, because it was a little surprising getting a notice from the
speaker that he would be calling, and then even more surprising to be on the alert for
"Spam risk Egypt," and then he just advised me that he would be asking for whether or
not I would be interested in coming to Washington, D.C., very quickly afterwards.
And that was the extent of what I remember about that interaction, because I was
already thinking about the logistics, because it was inferred that it was going to be pretty
Did Mr. Chatfield tell you what the purpose of the meeting at the White
House was or was going to be?
So you said you received a call on the evening of November 18th.
phone indicate that it was a call coming in from Egypt?
And was President Trump on the line?
You know, there were more than one call -- there was more than one call,
and I do believe it may have been a call or two -- again, I'm just going by memory here
that's not good -- where it might have been a secretary announcing him.
me that one was directly from him.
But I could be mistaken on that.
Now, the phone records reflect that the call lasted approximately 4 minutes.
What do you remember about taking place on that call?
I remember him introducing himself and inviting the speaker and I to
I also remember him saying, "If you want to bring along
some of your buddies, some of your colleagues, that's fine also."
Did he tell you what the purpose of the meeting was?
Did he ask you anything about the 2020 election in that phone call on the
He just -- he not say what the purpose of the meeting was.
He mentioned his concerns about the election and questioned
whether or not we were doing about it, and I mentioned to him that we were indeed
looking into some of the allegations that had been made.
He asked that question, and I said, yes, we were looking
into some of the allegations that had been made.
So the call was approximately 2 weeks after the election.
at that time of allegations of election fraud being raised in Michigan?
I was aware of a lot of allegations being made about election fraud across
Had you taken any steps as majority leader to have any of those claims
We assigned a senate oversight committee the job to begin to outline how
they would investigate some of the allegations in Michigan that seemed to be deserving
At the time was Senator Ed McBroom the chair of the oversight committee?
And did you authorize, if that's the right term, Senator McBroom to proceed
In the call with the President, did any of the details of the oversight
Anything else you remember about your discussion with the President
regarding election fraud claims in that first phone call on the 18th?
It was a very brief call.
And other than him asking the question of whether
or not we're aware of or looking into some of the allegations and me responding by
saying we are looking into it, I don't recall anything else.
Do you remember if he mentioned any specific allegations that were of
Did you end up going to Washington, D.C., to meet with the President?
Did you have any discussions with Speaker Chatfield in advance of that
meeting with the President to sort of discuss what might be the subject or the topic of
discussion that would come up at the meeting?
We anticipated that the conversation would likely get to what are we doing
in Michigan to investigate some of the allegations of fraud.
We also talked about let's make good use of this time.
with us a formal letter to the President asking for some specific considerations regarding
Federal funding associated with the COVID pandemic.
Did you discuss with Mr. Chatfield what your response would be if he asked
about election fraud claims in Michigan?
And what was -- can you describe what that conversation was with Speaker
We both concurred -- it wasn't a long conversation -- that we were going to
And tell that to the President?
I'm asking, sir, in the pre-meeting discussions with Speaker
Chatfield, did you discuss the fact that you would tell the President what you just said,
that we will follow the laws of Michigan?
Any other discussions with Speaker Chatfield beforehand about how
you might respond to specific election fraud claims?
Who else besides Speaker Chatfield accompanied you to Washington?
then I understand maybe a smaller group of the contingent or the delegation actually met
So in that larger group, who made the trip to Washington with you and Speaker
In addition to Speaker Chatfield and myself, we had Senators Barrett,
Lauwers, and Nesbitt, and Representatives Wentworth and Lilly, and then we each had
our own respective general counsels with us.
Do you recall approximately how long that meeting lasted in the Oval Office?
From the time we left the Roosevelt Building, I think it's called -- Eisenhower
And which members of that group actually attended the Oval Office
Building -- until the time we got back, it was approximately 90 minutes.
Who else, other than the Michigan delegation that you've described, who
else was present for the meeting in the Oval Office?
Physically present, all I recall is Mark Meadows.
Were there other people who participated by phone?
Who do you recall participating by phone?
I recall Ronna Romney McDaniel and Rudy Giuliani.
Do you know Ms. McDaniel from Michigan days?
I do know of her from her Michigan days, yes.
I take it, did you invite her to this meeting?
I don't think I invited her to the meeting, no.
And I take it the same is true for Mr. Giuliani, you didn't invite him to
And is that true for Ms. McDaniel, that she was not present on the phone
President Trump invited him to the meeting once the meeting started.
Neither Ronna nor Rudy were on the phone when the meeting started.
can you hold on a second?
We'll go back on the record.
So, Senator Shirkey, you said the meeting lasted about 90 minutes.
you just give us, before we get into the details, just a brief overview of what took place
And then I'll want to dig in on some of the specifics.
So we left the Eisenhower Building, made our way across the walkway, went
up through a narrow set of stairs, went into the reception area, which I believe was
immediately adjacent to the Oval Office.
Had an interaction with the receptionist for the United States of America.
Challenged her on that title that she got, and she showed me her business card.
indeed was the receptionist for the United States of America.
I don't think we were there more than 5 to 7 minutes.
And then we were escorted into the Oval Office.
And Mr. -- President Trump was behind his desk.
Came out from behind it and
And then there were seven chairs set up across the front of the desk, and we all
best of my recollection, he was there for the entire meeting.
Mark Meadows sat on the sofa behind us.
And then we ran through the cordials.
So everybody had a chance to introduce
themselves and where they're from in Michigan and maybe -- I think some of them even
acknowledged some of the committees that they serve on.
And then we started, began to have a conversation.
And then at one point in time, the President got up and went out in the Rose Garden for a
And then after that the conference call occurred with Ronna and with Giuliani.
We did have an entertaining interaction with the fellow that brought Diet Coke in to the
Then we finished up our conversations.
We concluded with a presentation of
our letter to him and explained the purpose of it.
And there were photo ops for all of
something he wanted the President to sign so he could have a signature from him.
One member, I think Senator Nesbitt actually had
And at that point in time, we departed from the Oval Office with Mark Meadows.
He took us on a detailed tour, a very interesting detailed tour of the Situation Room and
We spent not an insignificant amount chime in both of those locations because I
was full of questions regarding particularly the Situation Room.
number of scenarios in which he was actually present and personally was able to observe
with regards to things like rescuing people in remote parts of the world.
Then he presented to us some trinkets and souvenirs to leave with.
And we did not go back to see the President or the Oval Office.
So I want to focus on the portion, the conversation, what you described as sort of
the meeting starting after that, after the introductions, and so forth, but before the
President went out to the Rose Garden.
So what was the -- I assume the President at some point early on in that discussion
announced the reason that he had called you to Washington?
I don't think there was -- to the best of my recollection, I don't think there
was ever a formal statement of reason for coming, but there wasn't a mystery about it
either in terms of he's inquiring as to what Michigan is doing to investigate the allegations
Can you give us more specifics about what the President said about the
You know, I'm going to disappoint you a bit because there's not a lot of
specifics that he said that I'm going to remember directly.
remember the essence of the conversations.
I'm doing the best I can to
One thing I do remember is that he never, ever, to the best of my recollection,
hear about this or what are you doing about -- you know.
about Wayne County and TCF Center and all of the video that was shown on national TV
with respect to that and did it in the form of questioning what's actually going on there.
It was always just general topics about, you know, did you
He was a bit disparaging about Wayne County.
At one point in time I made it
clear to him that he didn't lose Michigan because of Wayne County.
could tell by his body language that wasn't necessarily what he wanted to hear.
Can I stop you there for one second?
What do you recall him saying that was disparaging of Wayne County?
Just that all of the chaos going on with TCF Center and the late night band
showing up that everybody has seen a thousand times on TV and the boxes being
unloaded, and then the inference that if none of that had happened he would have won
And that's not a true statement.
Did he make comments along the line of Detroit is corrupt or they're corrupt
in Detroit or in Wayne County, sort of broader statements about sort of his views of
Detroit politics, Wayne County politics, or elections?
I don't recall if he ever used the word "corrupt," but I do think he probably
referenced that Wayne County has a history.
And you said you made some response -- or responded to that by telling him
that's not why he lost Michigan.
Do you remember what you said to him in that regard?
I do, because I have had to repeat it a few hundred times to other people
I said he primarily lost Michigan because of two counties that are routinely
Republican counties, Kent County and Oakland County, and more specifically he
And I'm going to be even more specific.
If he had received the same number of
votes as the two winning sheriffs in those two counties, he likely would have won
So I take it by November 18th, 2 weeks after the election, you already had
fairly specific demographic information about how sort of the votes broke out in various
And do you know how he did in -- how the President did in Wayne County as
It was sliced and diced pretty well.
He actually outperformed considering the increase in voter turnout in 2020
underperform in Wayne County if you compare it to 2016.
It was not enough, obviously, to carry the election.
You said that when you made that comment to him he didn't seem to like
My recollection is he quickly changed the topic and went a different
direction, but don't ask me what that was because I don't remember that.
Do you remember what he said about concerns about the TCF Center
Can you believe all the cardboard that they
And can you believe the yelling and screaming that
And can you believe they locked certain people out who wanted ostensibly
There was a litany of those things that he was going through.
Did you push back on any of those claims?
No, because I didn't know enough at that time.
So the meeting was on -- I don't know if we even established this yet -- the
meeting was on November 20th, on a Friday.
So the evening before, or late in the afternoon before, on November 19th,
there was a press conference that Mayor Giuliani, Sidney Powell, and others held at the
Do you recall that press conference or anything about it?
It got a lot of national
Yeah, I don't remember any -- I remember many, watching many press
conferences, but I don't remember -- I don't recall any specific press conferences.
recall seeing Rudy Giuliani on television more often than I care to remember on this topic.
This is a press conference that got a lot of attention.
hair dye or what appeared to be hair dye running down his face during it.
was a lengthy discussion at the press conference by Sidney Powell and Mr. Giuliani about
Dominion voting machines and Hugo Chavez.
I'm just wondering if that rings a bell for
I can remember Giuliani mentioning Dominion voting machines.
not sure I remember it at that particular press conference.
And the reason I bring up the press conference is that the Oval Office
meeting was the day after, and I'm wondering whether -- for a lot of people that press
conference left a lasting impression, and whether that was something that was front of
mind for you or came up in the discussions during the White House meeting.
So when he was on the conference call in the Oval Office he was repeating
things that I had heard him say multiple times.
or not, to me, he hadn't changed his mantra much at all.
Whether or not it was the night before
Let's move to that part of the meeting.
So you had this initial discussion.
The President left the Oval Office for a period
of time, a few minutes, less than 10 minutes, and then came back in.
that point Ms. McDaniel and Mr. Giuliani joined by phone.
Am I getting that sequencing right?
How is it that they joined the conversation, if you know?
If I recall correctly, the President hit a button on his phone and had
He did not directly dial them.
But he requested that they be brought into the conversation, to your
Did the President bring Ms. McDaniel and Mr. Giuliani in at the same time or
was it at different points during the meeting?
I don't remember if they were on at the
same time or it was one call then the next one.
What do you remember Ms. McDaniel saying during that meeting?
It was a lot of, "Sorry I wasn't able to be there to see
my friends from Michigan, yada, yada, yada."
there was no real substance as relates to the election.
But there was no -- to my recollection,
Did Mr. -- did the President tell the group why he was bringing Ms. McDaniel
So, in other words, "Hey, I'm going to get Ronna McDaniel on for X, V, or Z
What do you recall his role being in the
There was an interaction between the President and us about questioning
how were we looking into allegations of fraud and so forth.
when we were talking about TCF and Wayne County and Oakland County and Kent
And I believe the strong inference from both Speaker Chatfield and I was that we
saw no reason for anything to be done on our end other than to investigate some of the
And he asked if you'd like to -- no.
What am I going to say?
He asked, "Would you mind if I dialed in
Yeah, I don't want Giuliani on the phone?
think even if I said no, he would have just done it anyway.
But that's the best of my recollection.
And when Mr. Giuliani came on the phone, did you get the sense that he was
or what you guys were doing when he was brought on the line?
Had he been sort of -- did he know what he was getting into
I don't think I recall vividly enough to be able to comment on that,
other than it didn't take him long to get into his routine.
He got up to top speed pretty quickly?
So tell me about what Mr. Giuliani said when he got on the line.
He started going through his litany of claims and observations that he's
made and the reasons why, in his opinion, the election was problematic, if not worse.
He was filibustering, is what he was doing.
Of everybody in that room, I'm not so sure he wasn't the one that talked the
longest of all of us for that entire time.
And was this -- was the President participating in that part of the discussion
or was Mr. Giuliani pretty much just on a long monologue?
He was on a long monologue.
And so I'm not sure if this was ever talked
about post-meeting, but I may have offended him a little bit because I did my best to
interrupt him because he was going -- literally going on and on and on.
getting to the point of uncomfortable.
"So when are you going to file charges, file a lawsuit in Michigan?"
been a 2-second void, and then he just kept talking.
So he didn't answer the question about when he would file the lawsuit?
Why did you feel the need to interrupt him to ask that question?
Did you find his presentation compelling in terms of the points that he was
I found that there was nothing new that I hadn't already heard.
Did any of the other members of the Michigan delegation speak up and
challenge Mr. Giuliani in the same way that you did?
I don't think anybody else spoke -- to the best of my recollection, I don't
think anybody else spoke while Rudy was speaking.
Did the President make any comments during Mr. Giuliani's lengthy
discussion about his concerns or claims about election fraud?
I don't -- I honestly don't recall.
Did the President respond in any way when you challenged Mr. Giuliani and
asked him when he was going to file a lawsuit?
I recall that he sat up a little bit, but he never said a word that I recall.
When you asked Mr. Giuliani whether he was going to file a lawsuit, what
did you mean by that or what was the point of making that -- or asking that question?
My point then, and it always has been, that I got -- I was tired of hearing all
of these loosely calculated claims and allegations but no substance to back them up.
Something as serious as this, it was my strong personal feeling that we were
destroying the country by talking like this without having something to follow it up with
and creating unnecessary doubt across the country.
Did you share that feeling explicitly at the meeting?
Did you ever say words to the effect that this is dangerous or we're
destroying the country by raising these claims without any evidence to back it up?
I'm not suggesting that you were raising these claims, I
raising these claims without evidence to back them up?
Did you suggest that it was irresponsible or dangerous for Mr. Giuliani to be
Did you say words to that
But that was the -- you asked what was
the reason for me to say it, and that was the reason for me, to try to get to the point.
At any point during the meeting did you tell the President your personal
view regarding the claims that had been raised regarding Michigan?
I told him about he didn't lose it because of Wayne County and all
the rest of the stuff I just shared with you.
How about concerns about whether there was evidence to back up those specific
Did you ever raise concerns or questions about that in your
That was a strongly implied question when I asked Rudy whether or not he
was ever going to file a lawsuit.
But I never mentioned it specifically.
Any other comments to Mr. Giuliani -- or did you make any other comments
to Mr. Giuliani along the same lines, expressing skepticism or challenging him with
respect to the claims that he made, other than the comment you described about the
At some point Mr. Giuliani stopped talking, I take it?
And then where did the meeting go from there?
It was terminated -- that call was terminated.
I don't think I -- I don't think there was any more exchange between Giuliani
I don't recall if it was
terminated by the President or by Giuliani.
After Mr. Giuliani was off the line, did your conversation with the President
brought up towards the end of the meeting, but was there any further discussion about
election fraud claims after Mr. Giuliani was off the line?
I know you've mentioned the COVID issue that you
It doesn't mean that it didn't happen.
was -- any comments that the President made regarding that, they were always just
Before I move on to another topic, -
So I'm going to -- I know you described some other things that took place in
that meeting, but I'm going to move on to sort of the post-meeting time period, Senator
So after the meeting, you and Speaker Chatfield issued a joint statement.
And we're going to pull up on the screen -- we'll share our screen, and
hopefully you can see it there.
You got a copy of it right there?
We're pulling up what's marked on our end as exhibit 2.
It's a different question of whether I can read it.
We can zoom in a little bit.
I just want to ask you generally if this looks like
Well, just give me a chance to look through it.
Why did you and Speaker Chatfield feel it was necessary to issue a statement
Because the meeting was not a very good secret, and so we just tried to
anticipate questions and basically engineer a response without having to endure a myriad
of different kinds of questions and kind of answer the essence of it and be able to put
I want to ask you a couple of questions about the last two paragraphs, the ones
that are on the screen now.
It's the paragraph beginning, "The Senate and House Oversight Committees
are actively engaged in a thorough review of Michigan's elections process."
"And we have faith in the committee process to provide greater transparency
Is that something that you conveyed to the President -- the substance of that, is
that something you conveyed to the President during your meeting?
I don't recall even mentioning the oversight committee to the President.
I'm just saying I don't recall that directly.
The next sentence says, "We have not yet been made aware of any
information that would change the outcome of the election in Michigan."
Do you know, is that something that you said in substance to the President during
other information beyond that, I probably would have shared it at that time.
I think that's the essence of me saying, "Mr. President, you didn't lose
You lost in two counties, Oakland and Kent County."
But that really was the essence of the message to him, that there's no -- we had
available to us no additional information that would cause us to question the outcome.
So I understand the point you just made.
I want to make sure so that I'm
clear on the words that were -- and I don't mean the exact words -- but sort of what was
actually said versus inferred or implied during that meeting.
So other than the reference to Oakland and Kent Counties and the reason that the
President lost and the implicit suggestion in your comment to Mr. Giuliani about the
lawsuit, did you make any other comments along the lines to suggest to the President
that you had not been made aware of any information that would change the outcome of
Did anyone else at that meeting, besides you, make a statement along those
I don't think any of our colleagues, other than the speaker and I, made any
regarding their position, their names, their locations, their interests, committees, et
But it was pretty much just the speaker and I and the President.
I think we have -- we can bring it up -- but we have a tweet from you at 6:13
So my understanding is this statement came out fairly shortly after you left
So is it fair to say that you had worked out or written up the statement
So that's within a couple of hours of you leaving
before you even went into the White House meeting?
We were talking about and contemplating how we were going to message
the fact that we actually went to the Oval Office before we went in so we were prepared
and didn't get caught off guard.
So we did discuss it before the meeting, yes.
How about the sentence that I was just focused on, that "We have not yet
been made aware of any information that would change the outcome of the election in
out or decided that you were going to say in the press statement before you went into
Is that something that you and Speaker Chatfield had already either written
This statement here was a joint effort between the [inaudible] group of the
None of these words are original words from Lee or I, the
But we read them and we may have edited them, but we accepted them.
I guess what I'm getting at is -- and I'm not trying to sort of put you on the
spot, but I think there's probably an answer to this question that you may be able to
It appears that before going into the meeting you and Speaker Chatfield had sort
of come to the view that you had not yet been made aware of any information that
would change the outcome of the election in Michigan.
And I'm wondering whether it was a conscious decision not to say that directly to
the President, which seemed like it was sort of directly relevant to the kinds of issues that
And I'm not casting any -I interrupted you.
I just wanted to say, I'm not casting any aspersions.
wondering whether you're able to share whether that was a conscious decision to not go
In fact, we may have said that to the President in one form or another.
I just don't remember every piece of that long conversation.
The statement goes on, "We will follow the law and follow the normal process
Was that an issue that came up in the Oval Office meeting, the issue of Michigan
law as it relates to electors for the electoral college?
My recollection that the business and the process of electors did not come
up in the Oval Office meeting.
Was that something that was coming up in Lansing or in your other sort of
Can you tell us about that?
We had a number of folks who from various angles had been suggesting not
just Michigan but other States contemplate challenging how the electors are established
and who is going to actually perform the final certification of the election.
two or three people specifically that brought that up to us.
Robert Norton, Ian Northrup -- what is his last name?
And then Phil I Kline was in the middle of that as well toward the end.
Those are the three that I recall specifically.
I get Norton and Northan mixed up.
And was it your -- you spoke directly to Mr. Norton and Mr. Northan about
this issue of the legislature appointing electors.
Do you know if Mr. Norton and Mr. Northan were talking to other members
of the Michigan Legislature on the same issue in the same time frame?
How soon after the November 2020 election were you made aware that this
was something that was being discussed by Mr. Norton, Mr. Northan, or others?
Now I've got to figure out the timing of when those first meetings
I have them in my notes here.
I do not recall the exact dates of the interactions with Robert Norton and Ian and
Even if you don't have an exact date, do you have a recollection that it was
shortly after the election, like within days or a week of the election?
I remember it was between the election and the electors event, and it was
skewed toward the end of that.
